title: [Large-Scale] Simulation/VR-Based Tool Utilization Strategies for University Mathematics Instructional Design: Focus on Equations, Graphs, Statistical Visualization, and Proof

context.prior_knowledge: Foundational mathematics concepts (functions, calculus, probability and statistics, proofs) and experience with educational tools (GeoGebra, Desmos, etc.), basic graph interpretation and data analysis competencies
context.additional_context: Instructional design curriculum for developing university mathematics instructional design tools: VR-based visualization and simulation of multivariable calculus proofs, probabilistic distribution exploration and statistical inference using simulation tools, automated formative assessment systems, and integration of mathematical concept error analysis.

learning_goals: Design effective teaching strategies for equations, functions, and statistics by applying ≥3 mathematical instructional design frameworks (e.g., multiple representation theory, cognitive load theory, situated learning theory) in simulation/VR environments and develop teaching strategies linked to mathematical proofs.

Develop ≥2 formative assessment-centered instructional materials (e.g., graph interpretation worksheets, probability simulation activity sheets, statistical distribution comparison charts) using learning design support tools.

Enhance digital design competencies for mathematical concepts (3D geometry modeling, dynamic equation visualization, statistical distribution simulation, probabilistic reasoning) with ≥20% improvement in pre-post assessments.

For a medium-sized group of 20 learners, select ≥3 flexible teaching strategies (e.g., differentiated instruction: tiered problem sets and proof difficulty adjustments; collaborative learning: graph interpretation group tasks and data analysis discussions; project-based learning: statistical analysis reports and visualization deliverables), and design teaching strategies that meet ≥4 out of 5 evaluation criteria (clarity, feasibility, effectiveness, mathematical accuracy, technology integration) through peer and instructor assessments.
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
